This is a simple packaging of Review Board. It currently requires manual configuration after initial installation.

There are a variety of changed going on through the code provided. Most of it is stable but all of it is designed to work together. If you are taking a package or to please ensure that you check the recipe's for dependencies or anything you might not want.
Here is the BIG KEY. SOHO is based around a share auth focusing on MySQL (not ldap, winbind, or anything else). This is further extended by support from nss-mysql and pam-mysql. That combined with a few tweaks, gives SOHO a simple single sign on application infrastructure. There are two siginificant tools that will not play this game though; poptop (pptpd daemon) and Samba. Both have their valid reasons. These are handled by using native authentication. But in each case all account information is still managed by a single web based application (still under development).
So, if you take something and it doesn't work, please check the recipe. There are no code changes, mostly just enabling saslauthd or mysql for applications (such as postfix reading it's list of active emails directly from postfix).
If you have ideas or suggestions contact gary.w.smith@primeexalia.com.
If you would like to provide some support for this project (for which we will also give credit to) please feel free to contact me. We are looking for people with good python (if we decided on RAA as our admin backend) or PHP (which we already have a chunk of tools in). There is always perl, but no one has asked to go that way yet.
To Build a base image using Fedora Core 6 as a standard for our organizations principle productions systems.

This is an appliance build for the Simple Machines Forum (simplemachines.org). The appliance is used to install the SMF software with just enough operating system and other software to support the application. The current appliance release includes: * SMF 1.1.6 as distributed from simplemachines.org * PHP 5 * MySQL 5
The project home page describes this project in greater detail, including development notes.

There are a variety of changed going on through the code provided. Most of it is stable but all of it is designed to work together. If you are taking a package or to please ensure that you check the recipe's for dependencies or anything you might not want.
Here is the BIG KEY. SOHO is based around a share auth focusing on MySQL (not ldap, winbind, or anything else). This is further extended by support from nss-mysql and pam-mysql. That combined with a few tweaks, gives SOHO a simple single sign on application infrastructure. There are two siginificant tools that will not play this game though; poptop (pptpd daemon) and Samba. Both have their valid reasons. These are handled by using native authentication. But in each case all account information is still managed by a single web based application (still under development).
So, if you take something and it doesn't work, please check the recipe. There are no code changes, mostly just enabling saslauthd or mysql for applications (such as postfix reading it's list of active emails directly from postfix).
If you have ideas or suggestions contact gary.w.smith@primeexalia.com.
If you would like to provide some support for this project (for which we will also give credit to) please feel free to contact me. We are looking for people with good python (if we decided on RAA as our admin backend) or PHP (which we already have a chunk of tools in). There is always perl, but no one has asked to go that way yet.

This appliance features the memcached daemon from Danga Interactive. The daemon will start and use all available memory, so very little interaction should be needed. see http://www.danga.com/memcached/ for more information about this project.

The LAMP Appliance brings the best of breed Web application tools together in one easily-deployable form factor. From the Apache Web server, to your choice of databases (MySQL and PostgreSQL), to the three preeminent scripting languages (Perl, PHP, and Python), the Linux-based LAMP Appliance gives you the foundation for the database-backed Web application of your choice.
Getting Started
The fastest way to get started is to download one of the virtual appliance images and boot it. Alternatively, you can download the ISO images and complete the graphical installation to install LAMP appliance on a dedicated system.
- Login as root, no password required. - Place your content in /srv/www/ - For details on configuring a database, see http://wiki.rpath.com/wiki/Appliance:LAMP_Appliance
Support
LAMP appliance is a community supported project. Questions about LAMP appliance should be raised on the LAMP appliance discussion list: http://www.rpath.org/rbuilder/project/lamp/mailingLists

An appliance that bundles up PHP5, MySQL, Apache, Moodle and the rPath Appliance Agent to provide a self-contained, turn-key, updatable Moodle appliance.
Initial console userid/password
root/<none>
Initial rAA userid/password
admin/password
Release Notes
Upon First visit to your Moodle Appliance website you will be presented with the installer if you accept the defaults for all server setting the Moodle Appliance will configure perfectly (any changes will require you to make changes on the command line as well).
The Moodle Appliance now reports its IP address and configuration URL in the console on startup, so you no longer need to login to figure out how to connect and configure this appliance. See the Project Home page for updated installation instructions.
To manage or update your appliance:
This appliance includes the rPath Appliance Agent (rAA), a web-based appliance management console. The rAA console allows you to:
- retrieve an install updates for the appliance
- configure the appliance's network settings
- reboot your appliance
In order to access the rAA console, enter:
https://<appliance-ip>:8003/
into your web browser. The default rAA user is 'admin' with password 'password'.

Open source SugarCRM appliance
This appliance installs Linux as well as versions of mysqld and httpd that start on boot and the rAA system management web interface
Additionally, during the install sugar-preconfig can be selected to have the appliance set up SugarCRM so that when the install is done there is no need to go through the SugarCRM install screens; this option is selected by default.
The default sugar user is 'admin' and the default password is 'changeme' if you use sugar-preconfig
The default system root password for vmware is blank, so just login as root with no password
The default user for the mysql database for sugarcrm is 'sugarcrm' with password 'changeme'
The default privileged user for mysql is 'root' with no password
The default rAA user is 'admin' with password 'password'

This project was originally created to provide a complete appliance development environment, especially for those working through Application to Appliance: The Hands-on Guide (wiki.rpath.com/wiki/Application_to_Appliance).
Now this has been replaced by the new rPath Platform Development Image at (devimage.rpath.org), also here on rBuilder Online.
CURRENT USERS: You can continue to update your environment from the app2app labels for a while to come, but plan to migrate to the devimage labels sometime before July 2009.
NEW USERS: Go to devimage.rpath.org to locate and download images and for some initial instructions for deploying your development system.
For news and update announcements, and to ask questions about this project, see its rPath Forum thread: http://forum.rpath.com/index.php?topic=14.0

Gallery versions 1.5.6 and 2.2.1 are currently included.

Base Amazon Machine Image project.
Has just the essentials for developing against the EC2 platform. Both public AMI and Xen Filesystem versions are available. The filesystem version is good for local dev/test.
This image supports booting with an EC2 ssh keypair for secure login.
rAA 2.0 is also included and you can now pass the initial rAA admin password as EC2 userdata at boot time.
Format of the EC2 userData is:
[rPath] rap-password = new_password
If you do not pass in the rAA admin password, it will default to admin/password.
Please be sure to secure your EC2 VLAN so that only you have access to rAA's web console on port 8003 (https) or port 8004 (http)

lochDNS provides a web-configured software appliance for DNS services, based on MyDNS, MyDNSConfig, MySQL, the Apache web server, and PHP.
You can install an entire system with an anaconda-based installer, or you can use Xen, VMware, Parallels, or MS Virtual Server to run a guest OS for DNS service.

AliEn is a lightweight Grid framework built around Open Source components using a combination of Web Services and distributed agents. It was initially developed by the ALICE collaboration at CERN as a production environment for the simulation, reconstruction and analysis of physics data.

An appliance that provides a remote access to many common communication and development tools.
To manage the system, Remote Login Appliance provides the rPath Appliance Agent or rAA. Through rAA you can managed networking, update the machine, check system information, schedule a reboot, etc. The rAA management interface can be accessed at https://$hostname:8003. The initial user information is provided on the management page.

TeamSpeak is a voice-chat utility made popular by online gamers, but is not limited or restricted to games. It acts much like a VoIP application and requires only a microphone and supporting sound card. More information can be found at Wikipedia -- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teamspeak

Initial console userid/password
root/<none>
Initial rAA userid/password
admin/password
Initial TeamSpeak superuser password
run as root /root/tss-passwords.sh
to display system userids and passwords.
http://<appliance-ip>/admin for TeamSpeak admin web interface.

Bongo is an easy-to-use mail and calendar system, offering a simple yet powerful user interface. The goal is to make sharing, organization, and communication simpler, quicker, and more useful.
Read more here http://www.bongo-project.org
We have two mailing lists For Developers bongo-devel@gna.org For Users bongo-users@gna.org
Appliance Notes Initial console userid/password root/<none> Initial rAA userid/password admin/password
To manage or update your appliance:
This appliance includes the rPath Appliance Agent (rAA), a web-based appliance management console. The rAA console allows you to: - retrieve an install updates for the appliance - configure the appliance's network settings - initially configure Bongo - reboot your appliance
In order to access the rAA console, enter:
https://<appliance-ip>:8003/ into your web browser. The default rAA user is 'admin' with password 'password'.
My new appliance
WordPress is an elegant, single-user blogging tool for experienced and aspiring bloggers alike. This appliance encapsulates Wordpress and all its dependencies to make hosting as painless as possible.

If you're already blogging with WordPress, you might want to investigate this multi-user version, WordPress MU. The main difference between the two is that WordPress MU was created for the sole purpose of allowing simultaneous blogs to exist within one installation. MU makes it possible for any one with a website to host their own blogging community, control and moderate all the blogs from a single dashboard.
This appliance will run with a minimal amount of initial configuration. Additional configurations can be done later.

The LAMP Appliance brings the best of breed Web application tools together in one easily-deployable form factor. From the Apache Web server, to your choice of databases (MySQL and PostgreSQL), to the three preeminent scripting languages (Perl, PHP, and Python), the Linux-based LAMP Appliance gives you the foundation for the database-backed Web application of your choice.
Getting Started
The fastest way to get started is to download one of the virtual appliance images and boot it. Alternatively, you can download the ISO images and complete the graphical installation to install LAMP appliance on a dedicated system.
- Login as root, no password required. - Place your content in /srv/www/ - For details on configuring a database, see http://wiki.rpath.com/wiki/Appliance:LAMP_Appliance
Support
LAMP appliance is a community supported project. Questions about LAMP appliance should be raised on the LAMP appliance discussion list: http://www.rpath.org/rbuilder/project/lamp/mailingLists

image.productName: Do Not Use Anything From This Project
image.buildName: Do Not Use Anything From This Project
image.productDescription: This project is strictly a testbed -- do *not* use anything you find here!
Assorted troves for build and testing.

Windmill is an Open Source AJAX Web UI Testing framework. The Windmill appliance was designed to work as a headless (i.e. simplistic and minimal) appliance where you can remotely conduct your tests. A Vnc server is automatically started on port 5901 for you, as well as SSH so you can get things rolling really quickly. The root user is currently assigned a predefined authorization ssh key for remote access. Note that this feature would have to be configured for your own keys.
Guided Tour appliances for rPath Appliance Experience

If you're already blogging with WordPress, you might want to investigate this multi-user version, WordPress MU. The main difference between the two is that WordPress MU was created for the sole purpose of allowing simultaneous blogs to exist within one installation. MU makes it possible for any one with a website to host their own blogging community, control and moderate all the blogs from a single dashboard.
This appliance will run with a minimal amount of initial configuration. Additional configurations can be done later.

An appliance that bundles up PHP, MySQL, Apache, Joomla! 1.5 and the rPath Appliance Agent to provide a self-contained, turn-key, updatable Joomla! 1.5 appliance.
Initial console userid/password
root/<none>
Initial rAA userid/password
admin/password
Release Notes
The Joomla! 1.5 Appliance now reports its IP address and configuration URL in the console on startup, so you no longer need to login to figure out how to connect and configure this appliance. See the Project Home page for updated installation instructions.
To manage or update your appliance:
This appliance includes the rPath Appliance Agent (rAA), a web-based appliance management console. The rAA console allows you to:
- retrieve an install updates for the appliance - configure the appliance's network settings - reboot your appliance
In order to access the rAA console, enter:
https://<appliance-ip>:8003/
into your web browser. The default rAA user is 'admin' with password 'password'.
******Release 1.5 Additional Info******
When you first visit your new Joomla! 1.5 install you will have a 7 Step Installation that is very straight forward here is some additional help to get you going quickly.
Step 4. (defaults will work just fine)
Database type = mysql Host Name = localhost User Name = root Password = " " (blank/none) Database Name = joomla (you can insert anything here and it will make that your database name, "joomla" keeps it simple.)
---> next
Step 5.
You can ignore and goto ---> Next
6.
Site Name = "Whatever you want" , "John Does Joomla! 1.5 Website" Your email = me@somedomain.com Admin Password = pick_a_good_one Confirm Admin Password = pick_a_good_one
If you would like the Sample website Content installed push the button "Install Sample Data" if not goto ----> Next
You are now Done with the install script but before the site is completely usable you will need to goto the console and remove the install folder.
To do this log in to the console with the username of root (no password is required unless you set one using raa) and run:
[root@localhost ~]# rm -rf /srv/joomla/installation
Go back to your web browser and hit refresh and you site will be visible.

This is an appliance build for the Simple Machines Forum (simplemachines.org). The appliance is used to install the SMF software with just enough operating system and other software to support the application. The current appliance release includes: * SMF 1.1.6 as distributed from simplemachines.org * PHP 5 * MySQL 5
The project home page describes this project in greater detail, including development notes.

This is not the project you're looking for.
Trivial syslog appliance for monitoring purposes.

Open source SugarCRM appliance
This appliance installs Linux as well as versions of mysqld and httpd that start on boot and the rAA system management web interface
Additionally, during the install sugar-preconfig can be selected to have the appliance set up SugarCRM so that when the install is done there is no need to go through the SugarCRM install screens; this option is selected by default.
The default sugar user is 'admin' and the default password is 'changeme' if you use sugar-preconfig
The default system root password for vmware is blank, so just login as root with no password
The default user for the mysql database for sugarcrm is 'sugarcrm' with password 'changeme'
The default privileged user for mysql is 'root' with no password
The default rAA user is 'admin' with password 'password'

An appliance that bundles up PHP, MySQL, Apache and MediaWiki to provide a self-contained, turn-key Wiki appliance.
After a simple web-based configuration step, you'll be up and running and able to create and manage content collaboratively using the same software that powers Wikipedia.
This community appliance is hosted on rBuilder Online, where you can join mailing lists and also become a developer on this project if you wish.
Full installation notes can be found on the Project Home Page
Download the appliance now from rBuilder Online at http://www.rpath.org/rbuilder/project/mediawiki
Notes:
The MediaWiki Appliance reports its IP address and configuration URL in the console on startup, so you do not need to login to figure out how to connect and configure this appliance. See the Project Home page for updated installation instructions.
To manage or update your appliance:
This appliance is built on the rPath Appliance Platform, which includes a web-based appliance management console. The admin console allows you to: - retrieve an install updates for the appliance - backup and restore your appliance data - configure the appliance's network settings - reboot your appliance
In order to access the admin console, enter: https://<appliance-ip>:8003/ into your web browser. The default admin user is 'admin' with password 'password'.
Support
MediaWiki Appliance is a community supported project. Questions about MediaWiki Appliance should be raised on the MediaWiki Appliance discussion list: http://www.rpath.org/rbuilder/project/mediawiki/mailingLists
You can also discuss the project using the discussion facilities on the Project Home page above.

rPath Linux provides a reference platform for the creation of software appliances or purpose-built distributions. Using rBuilder, customers can mold rPath Linux to suit their unique application requirements. rPath Linux is a high-quality implementation of open source technologies that closely tracks stable upstream project sources. rPath offers optional support and maintenance for rPath Linux to customers requiring it.

lochDNS provides a web-configured software appliance for DNS services, based on MyDNS, MyDNSConfig, MySQL, the Apache web server, and PHP.
You can install an entire system with an anaconda-based installer, or you can use Xen, VMware, Parallels, or MS Virtual Server to run a guest OS for DNS service.

The LAMP Appliance brings the best of breed Web application tools together in one easily-deployable form factor. From the Apache Web server, to your choice of databases (MySQL and PostgreSQL), to the three preeminent scripting languages (Perl, PHP, and Python), the Linux-based LAMP Appliance gives you the foundation for the database-backed Web application of your choice.
Getting Started
The fastest way to get started is to download one of the virtual appliance images and boot it. Alternatively, you can download the ISO images and complete the graphical installation to install LAMP appliance on a dedicated system.
- Login as root, no password required. - Place your content in /srv/www/ - For details on configuring a database, see http://wiki.rpath.com/wiki/Appliance:LAMP_Appliance
Support
LAMP appliance is a community supported project. Questions about LAMP appliance should be raised on the LAMP appliance discussion list: http://www.rpath.org/rbuilder/project/lamp/mailingLists

Sugar Community Edition 5.1 in italiano, mandaci i tuoi commenti a dolcevita@openliven.com - SugarCRM Community Edition 5.1 Italian, please send your comments to dolcevita@openliven.com
This is the list of username/passwords of DolceVita - we strongly suggest to change them as soon as possible!!
sugarcrm admin: admin/admin rpath admin (https://<ip_address>:8003/): admin/password mysql: root/admin (database sugarcrm) !!be carefull because you can login also from a remote host!!
note: per Citrix XenServer you need to setup the network after importing the appliance in XenCenter
You can use PuTTY to ssh to the virtual machine, but first you need to setup a root password: 1. go to https://<ip_address>:8003/ (accept the certificate even if it is trusted) and follow all the required steps 2. once you are done, click "Configuration" on the left side and then Root Password
If you would like to send us comments, suggestions... or simply fill a bug report, please send us an email to dolcevita@openliven.com

Guided Tour project to show off the capabilities of the rPath Appliance Platform.
This appliance bundles up PHP, MySQL, Apache, MediaWiki and the rPath Appliance Platform to provide a self-contained, turn-key, updateable Wiki appliance.
Note that for use with Amazon EC2, root login has been disabled. Use a private/public keypair for direct shell access.
The default rPath Appliance Platform web UI user/password is admin/password. Note that you can also pass this in as EC2 user data:
[rPath] rap-password = new_password
This ensure that your instances on EC2 cannot be accessed by unauthorized users.
See the Project Home page for updated installation instructions.
To manage or update your appliance:
This appliance includes the rPath Appliance Agent (rAA), a web-based appliance management console. The rAA console allows you to: - retrieve an install updates for the appliance - configure the appliance's network settings - reboot your appliance
In order to access the rAA console, enter: http://<appliance-ip>:8004/ into your web browser.
Support

Questions about MediaWiki Appliance should be raised on the MediaWiki Appliance discussion list: http://www.rpath.org/rbuilder/project/mediawiki/mailingLists You can also discuss the project using the discussion facilities on the Project Home page above.

Openfire (formerly Wildfire) is a real time collaboration (RTC) server dual-licensed under the Open Source GPL and commercially. It uses the only widely adopted open protocol for instant messaging, XMPP (also called Jabber). Openfire is incredibly easy to setup and administer, but offers rock-solid security and performance.

FlatPress is an open-source standard-compliant multi-lingual extensible blogging engine which does not require a database to work.
You don't need MySQL because FlatPress stores all of its content on text files.

lochDNS provides a web-configured software appliance for DNS services, based on MyDNS, MyDNSConfig, MySQL, the Apache web server, and PHP.
You can install an entire system with an anaconda-based installer, or you can use Xen, VMware, Parallels, or MS Virtual Server to run a guest OS for DNS service.
This is a test project to build a functional rPath Linux for EC2 deployment as a telephony server

The LAMP Appliance brings the best of breed Web application tools together in one easily-deployable form factor. From the Apache Web server, to your choice of databases (MySQL and PostgreSQL), to the three preeminent scripting languages (Perl, PHP, and Python), the Linux-based LAMP Appliance gives you the foundation for the database-backed Web application of your choice.
Getting Started
The fastest way to get started is to download one of the virtual appliance images and boot it. Alternatively, you can download the ISO images and complete the graphical installation to install LAMP appliance on a dedicated system.
- Login as root, no password required. - Place your content in /srv/www/ - For details on configuring a database, see http://wiki.rpath.com/wiki/Appliance:LAMP_Appliance
Support
LAMP appliance is a community supported project. Questions about LAMP appliance should be raised on the LAMP appliance discussion list: http://www.rpath.org/rbuilder/project/lamp/mailingLists

Bongo is an easy-to-use mail and calendar system, offering a simple yet powerful user interface. The goal is to make sharing, organization, and communication simpler, quicker, and more useful.
Read more here http://www.bongo-project.org
We have two mailing lists For Developers bongo-devel@gna.org For Users bongo-users@gna.org
Appliance Notes Initial console userid/password root/<none> Initial rAA userid/password admin/password
To manage or update your appliance:
This appliance includes the rPath Appliance Agent (rAA), a web-based appliance management console. The rAA console allows you to: - retrieve an install updates for the appliance - configure the appliance's network settings - initially configure Bongo - reboot your appliance
In order to access the rAA console, enter:
https://<appliance-ip>:8003/ into your web browser. The default rAA user is 'admin' with password 'password'.

image.buildName: Virtual Cluster for Amazon EC2 service
image.productDescription: Virtual Cluster is an attempt to create an image for the Amazon EC2 service that can be used as a Computational Cluster.

This is the prototype software appliance from Replicate Technologies.

Guided Tour project to show off the capabilities of the rPath Appliance Platform.
This appliance bundles up PHP, MySQL, Apache, SugarCRM and the rPath Appliance Platform to provide a self-contained, turn-key, updateable CRM appliance.
Note that for use with Amazon EC2, root login has been disabled. Use a private/public keypair for direct shell access.
The default rPath Appliance Platform web UI user/password is admin/password. Note that you can also pass this in as EC2 user data:
[rPath] rap-password = new_password
This ensure that your instances on EC2 cannot be accessed by unauthorized users.
See the Project Home page for updated installation instructions.
To manage or update your appliance:
This appliance includes the rPath Appliance Agent (rAA), a web-based appliance management console. The rAA console allows you to: - retrieve an install updates for the appliance - configure the appliance's network settings - reboot your appliance
In order to access the rAA console, enter: http://<appliance-ip>:8004/ into your web browser.
Support
SugarCRM Appliance is a community supported project. Questions about SugarCRM Appliance should be raised on the SugarCRM Appliance discussion list: http://www.rpath.org/rbuilder/project/mediawiki/mailingLists You can also discuss the project using the discussion facilities on the Project Home page above.

FlatPress is an open-source standard-compliant multi-lingual extensible blogging engine which does not require a database to work.
You don't need MySQL because FlatPress stores all of its content on text files.
You really don't want to use anything here. Trust me.
Guided Tour appliances for rPath Appliance Experience

Base Amazon Machine Image project.
Has just the essentials for developing against the EC2 platform. Both public AMI and Xen Filesystem versions are available. The filesystem version is good for local dev/test.
This image supports booting with an EC2 ssh keypair for secure login.
rAA 2.0 is also included and you can now pass the initial rAA admin password as EC2 userdata at boot time.
Format of the EC2 userData is:
[rPath] rap-password = new_password
If you do not pass in the rAA admin password, it will default to admin/password.
Please be sure to secure your EC2 VLAN so that only you have access to rAA's web console on port 8003 (https) or port 8004 (http)

FlatPress is an open-source standard-compliant multi-lingual extensible blogging engine which does not require a database to work.
You don't need MySQL because FlatPress stores all of its content on text files.

Open source SugarCRM appliance
This appliance installs Linux as well as versions of mysqld and httpd that start on boot and the rAA system management web interface
Additionally, during the install sugar-preconfig can be selected to have the appliance set up SugarCRM so that when the install is done there is no need to go through the SugarCRM install screens; this option is selected by default.
The default sugar user is 'admin' and the default password is 'changeme' if you use sugar-preconfig
The default system root password for vmware is blank, so just login as root with no password
The default user for the mysql database for sugarcrm is 'sugarcrm' with password 'changeme'
The default privileged user for mysql is 'root' with no password
The default rAA user is 'admin' with password 'password'
This project is to create a firewall/gateway device with functionality similar to the common Linux firewall systems available today (smoothwall, shoreline, endian, etc).
